1. Set server address (IP address or host name). If the value entered is not a valid host name or IP address, it will be displayed in red text. This does not necessarily indicate an error—it is simply an indication that an error might occur when the VR Juggler application is run.
  2. Set server listening port (TCP = 6000, UDP = 5000). TCP is generally the best option.
  3. Indicate whether the named chassis is a master or a slave. The chassis will only be a slave when multiple packs are used. In that case, there will be one master chassis and one or more slaves.
  4. Set the hemisphere of the transmitter within which the user(s) will be operating.
  5. Set the data format to be used by the sensors. Currently, only the format Position and Angles is known to work reliably.
  6. Choose the sample mode. Using Run Continuous will be the most efficient because the driver will not have to make repeated requests for samples, thereby saving bandwidth and computation cycles on the MotionStar chassis and on the machine where the Gadgeteer driver is running.
  7. Set the report rate for the sensors. This determines how frequently the sensors send data to the MotionStar chassis. A value of 1 indicates that they should send data every cycle. A value of 2 indicates that they should send data every other cycle, and so on.
  8. Set the measurement rate for the chassis. This value depends on the configuration of the hardware. The factory default is 86.1. An invalid value will have a negative impact on the quality of the tracking data.
  9. Set the physical units of the data returned by the sensors. Currently, the MotionStar Wireless tracking system only returns data in Inches.
  10. Configure the position and orientation of the MotionStar Wireless transmitter (the large black box) relative to the VR Juggler coordinate frame. This process configures what is known as a "position transform filter." The panels titled "Orientation" and "Position" present an easy way to perform this task.
